caption:
Table 1: 
Architecture Configuration of MaskGen.
Following prior work, we scale up MM-DiT blocks across two configurations.
description: This table presents the architecture configurations for two variants of the MaskGen model: MaskGen-L and MaskGen-XL.  It details the number of parameters, depth, width, MLP size, and number of heads in the MM-DiT blocks used in each model. The table highlights that the MM-DiT blocks are scaled up across two different configurations, following previous work, to achieve varying model sizes and capacities.

caption: Table 2: Ablation on Improved One-Stage Training Recipe. Both models are trained and evaluated on ImageNet.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study comparing the performance of the original TiTok model's two-stage training process against a newly proposed improved one-stage training method.  Both training methods are evaluated using the same framework and dataset (ImageNet) allowing for a direct comparison of their effectiveness in training a Vector Quantized (VQ) image tokenizer. The table shows that the one-stage method leads to significant improvements in both reconstruction quality (measured by rFID) and image quality (measured by Inception Score, IS).

caption:
Table 3: Ablation on Text-Aware De-tokenization Design.
To ensure fairness, all models are trained using our improved one-stage training recipe on the DataComp dataset and evaluated in a zero-shot setting on the ImageNet validation set. Relative improvements for text-aware variants are highlighted in blue. #: Number of tokens. c: Channels of continuous tokens.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the design of text-aware de-tokenization.  The goal is to assess the impact of incorporating textual information during the de-tokenization phase of the image tokenizer. Multiple models were trained using the improved one-stage training recipe and the DataComp dataset.  Performance is evaluated in a zero-shot setting on ImageNet's validation set, using reconstruction FID (rFID) and Inception Score (IS).  The table compares different configurations: discrete and continuous tokens with varying numbers of tokens and channels.  Relative improvements for text-aware versions are highlighted.  This allows for analyzing the contributions of different components (discrete vs continuous tokens, number of tokens, and channels) to the model's performance.

content:
tokenizer arch #tokens text guidance rFID↓↓\downarrow↓ IS↑↑\uparrow↑
TA-TiTok KL 32 ID 1.62 213.6
Embedding 1.53 222.0
caption:
Table 4: Ablation on Text Guidance Type.
Models are trained on DataComp and zero-shot evaulated on ImageNet validation set.
ID refers to numerical IDs extracted by CLIP text tokenizer, Embedding denotes text features extracted by CLIP text encoder.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the type of text guidance used in the Text-Aware Transformer-based 1-Dimensional Tokenizer (TA-TiTok).  Two variants are compared: one using numerical IDs extracted directly from the CLIP text tokenizer and the other using the full text embeddings from the CLIP text encoder. The models were trained on the DataComp dataset and evaluated using zero-shot image generation on the ImageNet validation set. The results demonstrate the impact of different text guidance methods on the model's performance.

caption:
Table 5: 
Zero-Shot Text-to-Image Generation Results on MJHQ-30K.
Comparison of MaskGen with state-of-the-art open-weight models.
“VQ” denotes discrete tokenizers and “KL” stands for continuous tokenizers.
“type” indicates the generative model type, where “AR”, “Diff.” and “Mask.” refer to autoregressive models, diffusion models and masked transformer models, respectively.
T: Generator training cost, measured in 8 A100 days using float16 precision. I: Generator inference throughput, measured in samples per second on a single A100 with batch size 64 using float16 precision. We compare inference throughput with methods using the same resolution.
description: This table presents a comparison of MaskGen's zero-shot text-to-image generation performance on the MJHQ-30K benchmark against several state-of-the-art models that use publicly available data.  The table shows MaskGen variants using both discrete (VQ) and continuous (KL) tokenizers, along with their respective training costs (in 8 A100 days), inference speeds (samples per second), and FID scores.  For comparison, autoregressive (AR), diffusion (Diff), and masked transformer (Mask) models are included, highlighting MaskGen's competitive performance and efficiency.

description: Table 6 presents a comparison of the MaskGen model's performance on the GenEval benchmark against other state-of-the-art open-weight text-to-image generation models.  The table evaluates zero-shot performance, meaning the models were not fine-tuned on the GenEval dataset.  Metrics shown likely include scores for several aspects of image quality, such as the semantic alignment between the generated image and the input text prompt.

caption:
Table 7: 
Training Data Details.
Filtering criteria applied to each publicly available dataset include resolution (aspect ratio < 2 and longer side ≥\geq≥ 256), aesthetic score (predicted score exceeding the specified value in parentheses), and watermark detection (removal of images predicted to contain watermarks). For datasets with noisy web-crawled captions, Molmo [16] is used for recaptioning.
The final column shows the number of text-image pairs remaining after filtering.
description: This table details the datasets used for training the TA-TiTok tokenizer and MaskGen models.  For each dataset, it specifies the filtering criteria applied: resolution (images with an aspect ratio less than 2 and a longer side of at least 256 pixels), aesthetic score (only images with scores above a certain threshold were kept, as indicated in parentheses), and watermark detection (images with detected watermarks were removed).  Datasets with noisy or low-quality captions were improved using the Molmo model [16] for recaptioning. The final column shows the number of text-image pairs remaining after applying these filters.

caption:
Table 9: Ablation on Text Guidance Place.
In the TA-TiTok design, we ablate on adding the text guidance to both encoder and decoder or just decoder.
Adding text guidance to only the decoder results in similar reconstruction performances but enjoys a simpler structure.
Models are trained on DataComp and zero-shot evaulated on ImageNet validation set.
description: This table investigates the impact of adding text guidance to the TA-TiTok model. It compares the reconstruction performance when text guidance is added to both the encoder and decoder versus only the decoder. The results show that adding text guidance to only the decoder achieves similar reconstruction performance with a simpler model architecture. The models were trained using the DataComp dataset and evaluated using zero-shot testing on the ImageNet validation set.

caption:
Table 10: 
Comparison of MaskGen using Discrete and Continuous Tokens on MJHQ-30K and GenEval.
“VQ” denotes discrete tokenizers and “KL” stands for continuous tokenizers.
“type” indicates the generative model type, where “Mask.” refer to masked transformer models.
T: Generator training cost, measured in 8 A100 days using float16 precision. I: Generator inference throughput, measured in samples per second on a single A100 with batch size 64 using float16 precision. FID: MJHQ-30K FID. Overall: GenEval average score.
description: Table 10 presents a comparison of the MaskGen model's performance using both discrete (VQ) and continuous (KL) tokenizers.  The comparison is made across two key metrics: the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) score on the MJHQ-30K dataset, and the overall score from the GenEval benchmark.  The table also provides information on the training cost (measured in the number of days on 8 A100 GPUs) and the inference speed (samples per second on a single A100 GPU with a batch size of 64) for each model variant.

caption:
Table 11: 
Zero-Shot Text-to-Image Generation Results on MJHQ-30K and GenEval with Varying Number of Tokens.
MaskGen achieves better generation quality with more tokens but incurs longer training times and slower inference speeds.
T: Generator training cost, measured in 8 A100 days using float16 precision. I: Generator inference throughput, measured in samples per second on a single A100 with batch size 64 using float16 precision.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on the number of tokens used in the MaskGen model for text-to-image generation.  It demonstrates that increasing the number of tokens generally improves generation quality (measured by FID and GenEval scores), but at the cost of increased training time and reduced inference speed.  The table also provides the training cost (T) in terms of 8 A100 days using float16 precision and inference throughput (I) in samples per second (using a single A100 GPU and batch size of 64 with float16 precision).

caption:
Table 12: 
Zero-Shot Text-to-Image Generation Results on MJHQ-30K and GenEval with Ablation of Additional Conditions.
Incorporating aesthetic scores as conditioning signals enhances generation quality.
description: This table presents the results of a zero-shot text-to-image generation experiment using the MaskGen model.  The experiment compares the model's performance on two metrics (FID on the MJHQ-30K dataset and overall GenEval score) with and without incorporating aesthetic scores as an additional conditioning signal during generation. It demonstrates that incorporating aesthetic scores improves the quality of the generated images, resulting in better scores on both evaluation metrics.

It shows the FID scores achieved by different models, including various MaskGen configurations using different tokenizers (VQ and KL) and model sizes (MaskGen-L and MaskGen-XL). The table also includes information on the type of generative model (autoregressive, diffusion, masked), the number of parameters, and whether the model was trained using open-source data. This allows for a direct comparison of MaskGen's performance and efficiency against existing methods.

caption:
Table 14: Class-conditional ImageNet-1K 256×256256256256\times 256256 × 256 Generation Results Evaluated with ADM [19], using continuous tokens (i.e., KL architecture).
#: Number of tokens. c: Channels of continuous tokens. T: Generator training cost, measured in 8 A100 days using float32 precision. I: Generator inference throughput, measured in samples per second on a single A100 with float32 precision.
description: Table 14 presents a performance comparison of different configurations of the KL variant of TiTok (continuous tokens) on the ImageNet-1K dataset for class-conditional image generation.  The configurations vary the number of tokens and channels in the continuous embedding. The results are evaluated using the ADM metric [19], measuring both the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and the Inception Score (IS). The table also reports the generator training cost (in 8 A100 days using float32 precision) and inference throughput (samples per second on a single A100 with float32 precision) for each configuration. This demonstrates the impact of different token and channel configurations on both the quality and efficiency of image generation.
section: F. KL variant of TiTok on ImageNet
